Award.AwardTitle: Victims' Experiences of International Justice After Atrocity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research examines victims' assessments of procedural justice at the International Criminal Court (ICC). Created by the Rome Treaty in 1998, the ICC has been hailed as a new type of international court, one that promotes restorative justice for victims as well as accountability for grave international crimes. One of its innovations is to provide expansive procedural rights to victims, including the right for victims to present their concerns at different stages of the proceedings, subject to the discretion of judges. Yet no studies have examined how victims view their participation.

Drawing on in-depth interviews with more than 600 victims in Uganda, Democratic Republic of Congo, Kenya, and Cote d?Ivoire, we assess whether or not respondents 1) feel they havea voice in ICC proceedings; 2) view the ICC as a neutral arbitrator; 3) feel respected by Court staff; 4) trust the ICC; and 5) feel safe being associated with the Court. The study contributes to a growing literature on the importance of procedural justice for the legitimacy of judicial institutions, and provides important insights into victims' subjective assessments of the effectiveness of international criminal interventions after mass violence. By documenting for the first time the lived experiences of victims participating in ICC trials, the study provides insight into the social-psychological dynamics of victim participation and strengthens the functioning of international criminal justice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interventions of the International Criminal Court (ICC) have fostered hope for justice among survivors of war crimes and human rights violations in northern Uganda, eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, Ivory Coast and Kenya. But hope for what? Are victims seeking convictions? Punishment? Reparations? And how do victims view the Court after criminal cases collapse? The Rome Statute—the legal foundation underlying the ICC—created unprecedented procedural rights for victims in international criminal trials, enabling them for the first time to present concerns at any stage of the court proceedings subject to judicial approval.

The Human Right Center’s The Victims' Court? A Study of 622 Victim Participants at the International Criminal Court is the first multi-country attempt to understand how procedural justice works for victim participants at the International Criminal Court (ICC). We found that core procedural justice factors can look very different in transnational settings. Drawing on 622 in-depth interviews with ICC victim participants, our research suggests that core procedural justice principles—voice, neutrality, trust and respect—shift with cultural and institutional factors. Our findings identify additional factors, including participants’ physical safety, judicial timelines, and levels of institutional support, that affect participants’ subjective evaluations of procedural fairness. These findings suggest that researchers must rethink core principles of procedural justice in transnational settings. The work also contributes to a growing literature on the importance of procedural justice for the legitimacy of judicial institutions.
